headline: Early Start with John Berman and Zoraida Sambolin
subHeadline: Today: Former Governor Nikki Haley Announces White House Bid; DOJ Tells Court There's Evidence of a Crime in Bid to Force Answers from Trump Attorney; Alex Murdaugh's Attorneys Considering Putting Him on Stand; Report: Russia Detaining Thousands of Ukrainian Children. Aired 5-5:30a ET

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Right now on EARLY START, the Republican race for president, Trump and Haley are in. Who's next?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER) GOV. RON DESANTIS (R), FLORIDA:  Wouldn't you like to know? (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Plus, the plea deal that allowed the Michigan state gunman to legally buy guns before his campus rampage.And the risky move defense lawyers could make in the Alex Murdaugh trial. Will they put him on the stand in his own defense? (MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Welcome to our viewers in the United States and around the world. I'm Christine Romans.There are not two Republicans in the 2024 race for the White House. Former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley kicks off her bid for the presidency in a matter of hours. She'll become the first major rival to challenge her ex-boss, former President Trump for the GOP nomination. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) NIKKI HALEY (R), FORMER SOUTH CAROLINA GOVERNOR:  It's a time for a new generation of leadership, to rediscover fiscal responsibility, secure our border and strengthen our country, our pride and our purpose. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: The Haley campaign launch gets underway, today, in a Charleston South Carolina. CNN's Kylie Atwood is there.(BEGION VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: I'm Nikki Haley, and I'm running for president.KYLIE ATWOOD, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  Nikki Haley telling her story to the American people as a presidential candidate for the first time.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: I was the proud daughter of -- not black, not white, I was different. But my mom would always say your job is not to focus on the differences but the similarities. And my parents reminded me and my siblings every day how blessed we were to live in America.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: The 51-year-old, casting herself as the future of the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: It's time for a new generation of leadership.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: Urging the GOP to chart a new course.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: Republicans have lost a popular vote in seven out of the last eight presidential elections.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: In highlighting her accomplishments, as a two term governor of South Carolina, the state where she was born and raised.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: Every day is a great day in South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: Cutting taxes and leading her state through the aftermath of the 2015 deadly shooting by a white supremacist, at the Mother Emanuel AME Church in Charleston.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: We turned away from fear, towards God.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: At the time, really confronted a controversial issue, spearheading efforts to remove the Confederate flag from the state capital.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: The biggest reason that I ask for the flag to come down is that I cannot look my children in the face and justified standing there.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: In her announcement, Haley also nodding to her experience in the world stage, as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

utterances.speaker: HALEY
utterances.sentences: China and Russia are on the march. They all think that we can be bullied, kicked around, you should know this about me -- I don't put up with bullies. And when you kickback, it hurts them or if you're wearing heels.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: But no mention of former President Trump, who tapped her for that role.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I just want to thank Nikki. ATWOODREP. NANCY MACE (R-SC):  She's got all the qualifications to run for president.

utterances.speaker: ATWOOD
utterances.sentences: Even as some are concerned that a crowded primary could benefit former President Trump.

utterances.speaker: MACE
utterances.sentences: To see someone, see some of the leadership coming out of south, as exciting. But I do have concerns if there are too many people on the ballot by the time it gets to South Carolina that, you know, it lessens the chances of anyone sort of coming out in this thing.(END VIDEOTAPE) ATWOOD (on camera):  And, on Wednesday, Nikki Haley will make her pitch in person for the first time here in South Carolina, which is her home state. And, then she's off to the races, headed to New Hampshire, Iowa, to continue campaigning. Kylie Atwood, CNN, Charleston, South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: All right. Former Vice President Mike Pence hits the road today with visits to Minneapolis and Cedar Rapids. Pence is mulling a potential presidential run in 2024.CNN has learned he plans to fight a recent subpoena from the special counsel, investigating former President Trump's post-2020 election activities. Sources say Pence plans to argue he was president of the Senate at the time, which shields him from having to comply. But Florida Governor Ron DeSantis not officially in the 2024 race yet, and not giving any hints to reporters. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Nikki Haley announced her presidential run today. Do you plan on following suit?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DESANTIS
utterances.sentences: Wouldn't you like to know?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Big laugh there.Polls show the 2024 Republican primary is a two-man contest between former President Trump and DeSantis, with both men pulling over 30 percent, nationally. Prosecutors investigating former President Trump's handling of classified documents say that they have evidence of a crime. They're asking a court to force his attorney Evan Corcoran to give additional testimony. Corcoran already testified before a grand jury for four hours. [05:05:02] Prosecutors are trying to overcome the shield of attorney-client privilege, alleging Trump used Corcoran in the furtherance of a crime or fraud. A spokesman for the former president calls the move a witch hunt. All right. Alex Murdaugh's double murder trial resumes this morning with his attorneys now thinking about putting him on the stand in his own defense. The court heard from the sister-in-law about some of the strange comments Alex made to her after the murders. CNN's Randi Kaye has more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: MARIAN PROCTOR, SISTER OF MAGGIE MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: She loved her family. She loved her boys.RANDI KAYE, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  Maggie Murdaugh's sister, on the witness stand, just feet away from the man accused of taking the lives of her sister and her nephew, Paul Murdaugh. Marian Proctor shared in court that Maggie told her Alex had specifically requested she and Paul go to the family's hunting property that night.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She said that Alex wanted her to come home that night?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And what was your understanding of Maggie's intent or what they were going to do that night?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: I was under the impression they were going over to Almeda to visit his parents.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You encouraged her to go to Moza (ph)?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Was that the last time you talked to her?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Proctor shared how she felt after learning about their deaths.

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: I just couldn't believe it. I didn't think it was true.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Maggie Murdaugh's sister testified about what she described as an odd conversation she had with Alex in the days following the murders. She said when she asked him if Maggie and Paul had suffered, he assured her they did not.Then this -- PROCTOR:  I asked him, I said, Alex, do you have any idea who's done this? And I said, we have got to find out who could do this. And he said that he did not know who it was, but he felt like whoever did it had thought about it for a really long time.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That strike you as odd?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: I just didn't know what that meant.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: She also testified following the murders, Alex seemed focused on resolving a boat lawsuit his son Paul was involved in.

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: We would talk about the boat case and he was very intent on clearing Paul's name.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What did he say?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: He said that his number one goal was clearing Paul's name. And I thought that was so strange because my number one goal was to find out who killed my sister and Paul.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Regarding his whereabouts the night of the murders, Maggie's sister told the jury that Alex told her family that he had not gone to the dog kennels where the murders took place earlier that night.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And then he said he never went to the kennels?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Keep in mind, Alex told investigators he wasn't at the kennels either until much later that night, when he found his wife and son dead. Yet the state and more than half a dozen witnesses have identified his voice on a recording taken at the kennels around the time of the murders.The recording was discovered on Paul Murdaugh's cell phone months after the murders. On cross examination, the defense talked about Maggie being part of a loving family and how poorly Alex was coping with the murders.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Alex, was he grieving greatly?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Terribly.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And people have --

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Withdraw.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- described him as being destroyed, is that -- would you agree with that assessment?

utterances.speaker: PROCTOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Randi Kaye, CNN, Walterboro, South Carolina.(END VIDEOTAPE) ROMANS:  All right. Randi, thank you for that. A new report accuses Vladimir Putin of holding Ukrainian children in defensive camps. The study's author calling it, quote, a gigantic Amber Alert on Ukrainian children. CNN's Clare Sebastian live in London. These are thousands of children, this report reveals. What else do we know?

utterances.speaker: SEBASTIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, Russia, meanwhile via the Russian embassy in Washington has called the claims absurd saying that it accepts families, children including fleeing what it calls the atrocities committed by the armed forces in Ukraine and ensures the protection of their lives and well-being -- Christine.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Welcome back.Michigan State University has now identified the three students killed Monday night by campus gunman. Junior Arielle Anderson, sophomore Brian Fraser and Alexandria Verner, also a junior. Five other students remain in the hospital, in critical condition. CNN's Adrienne Broaddus has more on what happened and the investigation into the shooter. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: POLICE
utterances.sentences: We're going to need multiple, multiple ambulances.ADRIENNE BROADDUS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  The shootings at Michigan State University left three students dead and five others critically injured. Brian Fraser, a sophomore, and Alexandria Verner, a junior, were among those killed. The gunman, 43-year-old Anthony McRae, first opened fire on the campus Monday just before 8:30 p.m.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: CALLER
utterances.sentences: There's still people down there trying to get out.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: Shooting at two location locations, the first inside a classroom at Berkey Hall.INTERIM DEPUTY CHIEF CHRIS ROZMAN, MSU DEPT. OF POLICE & PUBLIC SAFETY:  While the officers were managing that scene at the hall, we began receiving additional reports of another shooting at the MSU Union Building.

utterances.speaker: POLICE
utterances.sentences: I'm coming down stairwell 13 with seven people.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: New video shows students hiding in a classroom, reacting to a knock while on the phone with police.

utterances.speaker: STUDENTS
utterances.sentences: Don't open the (EXPLETIVE DELETED) door!  Get the (EXPLETIVE DELETED) down!  They said don't open the door!

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: One witness to the shooting says his fight-or-flight response kicked in. DOMINIK MOLOTKY, STUDENT, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITYfar side of the class and ducked down, and he came in and shot three to four times in our classroom.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: Police released a photo of the shooter taken from campus security cameras and a caller's tip sent them to Lansing, Michigan.

utterances.speaker: MODERATOR
utterances.sentences: It's going to be a suspect wearing red shoes and a backpack.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: The search ended just before midnight.

utterances.speaker: POLICE
utterances.sentences: Shots fired.

utterances.speaker: POLICE
utterances.sentences: Shots fired, 23

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: Police said the gunman shot himself during a confrontation and died.

utterances.speaker: ROZMAN
utterances.sentences: We have absolutely no idea what the motive was at this point. We can confirm that the 43-year-old suspect had no affiliation to the university. He was not a student, faculty, staff, current or previous.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: According to police, they're now investigating a two-page note found in the gunman's backpack, saying he's going to, quote, finish off Lansing and that there are, quote, 20 of him who will carry out shootings, according to a source familiar with the investigation.Law enforcement now investigating a local residents, where the gunmen's father says he lived with him but. And two weapons. The shooter purchased two handguns in Michigan in 2021, a law enforcement source tells CNN.

utterances.speaker: ROZMAN
utterances.sentences: We do have at least one weapon.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: The gunman had been arrested before. He was released from probation in May of 2021 after pleading guilty to a misdemeanor for possession of a loaded firearm. MSU students are now dealing with what's next after spending hours hiding from a gunman.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM DIEDRICH, STUDENT, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: We took heavy furniture from around the library and just barricaded ourselves into a study room to make sure we were safe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I was, like, shaking in the bathroom, and it was just terrible. Just, like, preparing myself for, like, the worst thing ever.

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: Despite the tough circumstances, there's one greeting among all Spartans that still unites them.Go, green!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIIFED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Go, white!

utterances.speaker: BROADDUS
utterances.sentences: You guys smiled instantly. KELLY WEBB, STUDENT, MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITYdisgusting and tragic as that was, we are all in it together and everyone was here for each other. (END VIDEOTAPE) BROADDUS (on camera):  And that's a greeting that made them smile today, and it's one they learned during the freshman orientation. And it was needed, especially as the students learn more about that 43- year-old shooter, who police say had a note in his pocket threatening not one but two schools in New Jersey. And out of an abundance of caution, at least one of those schools did cancel classes on Tuesday. But police say there was no threat. They did say however that the 43- year-old shooter has ties to New Jersey. Adrienne Broaddus, CNN, East Lansing.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: All right, let's bring in senior news writer of "The Trace", Jennifer Mascia.So nice to see you this morning, again, under terrible circumstances. Let's talk about the shooter, suspected shooter. We know he was arrested in 2019, charged with felony, carrying a concealed weapon. They didn't have a weapon permit, but a change to a misdemeanor. Then, when he was discharged for probation, he was able to legally prestigious and possess a firearm again. I guess, Jennifer, that shows you that the bar is really high in this country to disarm someone.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: You know, Jennifer, "Washington Post" analysis counts 366 school shootings since the massacre in 1999. And here's East Lansing's mayor after that shooting at Michigan state. Listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAYOR RON BACON, EAST LANSING, MICHIGAN
utterances.sentences: We now have a complete generation that's going up with, this many times over as just a part of from elementary school all the way up to now and we're now looking at this as a college level as well. So, they level this the entire time.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: An entire generation of kids, who gun violence every day currency in their life. And, we know that there were kids there who experienced, who have experienced mass shootings twice in their life. I, guess what does that say about the debate here today?

utterances.speaker: MASCIA
utterances.sentences: Well, I -- by my count, there were at least four students at MSU who were survivors of previous mass shootings. One from Sandy Hook, and three from the Oxford High School shooting in Michigan, last 2021.So, I did not grow up with this, I think the generation after Columbine, you know, if you're into school at that time, you're used to, this is becoming your normal. Active shooter drills, threats of guns near campus that shut down school. And, now unfortunately, tragically, these school shootings. You, know we have kind of a limited window where this becomes normal for kids and they just developed a callous and it just becomes something that they have to deal with. But people who did not grow up with that, that is a lot to swallow. So, now you have people who have been through multiple mass shootings. And in America, actually, we have at least two dozen days throughout the year that have anniversaries of more than one mass shooting. So you could see how this is exhilarating and becoming the new normal for kids.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Wow, and then that begs the question, why and how do we fix it and that is a longer conversation with all kinds of pitfalls. No question.Jennifer Mascia, so nice to see you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MASCIA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: The death toll climbed to more than 41,000 after the catastrophic earthquake in Turkey and Syria. It reduced entire cities to piles of rocks and debris. Desperation has grown, even as rescuers are, somehow, finding people still alive in this rubble. Two people pulled out in just the past few hours.CNN's Nada Bashir live in Istanbul. And, Nada, crews are still looking to save people, aren't they?
